description: The MITS Altair 8800, introduced in January 1975, is widely regarded as the first true personal computer offered as an affordable, obtainable kit. For $395 users received a complete set of parts—metal chassis, power supply, passive motherboard with 100-pin Altair-bus slots, and a front panel laden with switches and LEDs. Assembly required days of careful soldering; the base unit shipped with only 256 bytes of RAM, so programs were entered in machine code via toggle switches and results read from blinking LEDs. The Intel 8080 CPU, secured by MITS in volume for about $75, sat on a plug-in card; memory, I/O and other functions resided on additional cards. This modular, open design fostered a cottage industry of third-party boards—memory, serial interfaces, video, floppy controllers—and quickly turned the Altair-bus into the de-facto S-100 standard. Although initially impractical for everyday use, the platform’s expandability and low entry price ignited the microcomputer revolution, attracting hobbyists, clubs and eventually software entrepreneurs. Within months optional BASIC from the newly-formed Micro-Soft turned the Altair into a programmable system, spawning user groups, magazines like BYTE and an ecosystem of compatible machines. Production peaked at thousands of units per month before MITS was sold to Pertec in 1976, but by then the Altair had already defined what a personal computer could be.
summary: The 1975 MITS Altair 8800 was a $395 build-it-yourself microcomputer based on the Intel 8080. Its 100-pin Altair-bus, later standardized as S-100, let users add memory, I/O and floppy cards, turning the blinking front-panel LEDs into an expandable system that sparked the personal-computer revolution.

description: The TFC 3450 was a business-oriented desktop computer produced by TRW-Fujitsu Co. of California. name: TI-99/4
description: The TI-99/4, launched by Texas Instruments in November 1979, was the company’s first home computer. Sold only as a $1,150 bundle with a 13-inch modified Zenith color monitor, the sleek console featured polished metal trim and a front cartridge slot. Its 16-bit TMS9900 CPU ran at 3 MHz, but only 16 KB of RAM and 26 KB of ROM were installed. BASIC execution was notoriously slow because code was interpreted twice—first by BASIC, then by TI’s proprietary Graphics Programming Language (GPL). The keyboard used low-profile chiclet keys reminiscent of calculators, reflecting TI’s calculator heritage and making touch-typing difficult. Expansion came via "sidecar" modules that daisy-chained from the right-hand bus; up to six could be attached, with the Speech Synthesizer required first and 32 KB Memory Expansion second. Available sidecars included RS-232, disk controller, dual 5¼-inch floppy drives, thermal printer, and an unusual Video Controller that could overlay computer output on a VCR signal and record data to videotape. Most commercial software shipped as ROM cartridges that plugged into the front port; over 80 unique titles existed. Although innovative for its time, the TI-99/4’s high price, limited RAM, awkward keyboard, and slow BASIC hampered adoption; it was superseded in June 1981 by the improved TI-99/4A.
